bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to the Librarian, Surgeon General's Library, September 17, 1940

div1.p: Hench asks to borrow E.B. Barnet's history of Las Animas Hospital. He comments on the role of Finlay in yellow fever research.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to the Librarian, Surgeon General's Library, September 17, 1940
div1.opener:
September 17, 1940
Librarian
Surgeon General's Library
Washington, D. C.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
Would it be possible for me to borrow, at your earliest conven-
ience the following item “El Hospital Las Animas.” Con un apendice por Juan Guiteras
y Mario G. Lebredo. Habana, 1904, 51 p. 10 pl, 2 plan., written by E. B. Barnet.
I understand there is an English text, and several photographs. If it is not
possible for me to borrow this directly, or through our Mayo Clinic library, would
it be possible for me to get a photostatic print of the photographs, maps and English
text, or a microfilm of the same? About how much would each of these cost?

I am to give an address on the conquest of yellow fever, at the
dedication of the Lazear Memorial Building, Washington and Jefferson College, Wash-
ington, Pa., October 26. On that occasion, Mr. Moran and Mr. Kissinger, the two
army privates who first volunteered to Walter Reed for experimental yellow fever,
will be present, as will Dr. Sawyer, director of the Rockefeller International
Foundation. In preparation for this address, I have corresponded and visited a
number of Walter Reed's associates and human guinea pigs, among them, General
Jefferson Kean of Washington, General Truby of California, and made a visit to Havana
this Spring. The Cuban government has successfully waged a campaign to deprive Reed
and the Army Commission of most of their glory and to indicate that Finlay deserved
practically all the credit. Part of this campaign is in the form of a book on Dr.
Finlay, just published this week by the Oxford Press, New York, and written by his
son in Havana, whom I also visited. It is my hope that I can not only prepare a
short address, but continue my historical researches and publish perhaps a small
historical monograph on the work of Reed et al, which would include some heretofore
most interesting and important unpublished data. Since much of the preliminary work
of Reed and his colleagues was done at Las Animas Hospital, I am most anxious to go
over in detail the above book which I understand is the only book on the history of
Las Animas Hospital that has ever been written. Do your files show any other history
of this hospital and do you know whether any history or article on Military Hospital
No. 1, Havana, Cuba (the first army hospital used by the American army in Cuba) has
ever been published? I cannot tell you how much I appreciate your kindness in this
matter.
I am enclosing an airmail stamped envelope for your reply.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
